A mum has described her terror after her previously healthy toddler became paralysed and mute after a family walk. 
Little Archie Adams, from Southampton, Hampshire, was a normal little boy who was developing well until May 2015. 
But suddenly, after a family day out to the local pub and a park, the 18-month-old lost control of his limbs and "went floppy". 
Twenty months on, his heart has stopped 12 times, he breathes through a tracheostomy tube and he is still unable to move. 
Heartbreakingly, doctors don’t believe he will ever move again. 
Archie's mum, Karen Adams, said: "It all happened so quickly, it was within minutes. It was like a light switch went off. Archie Adams suddenly "went floppy" after a family day out to a local pub and a park (Photo: PA Real Life) 
"He lost all control of all four limbs. They just went floppy like a newborn baby. 
“I was scared and felt lost. I didn’t know what was happening or what to think.” 
Karen, 35, has given up her job as a hospital catering assistant to care for her young son full-time. 
She described how Archie was walking in the landing of their home when he fell limp and stopped making any sound. Read More 
She and Archie's dad, former highways maintenance worker Russell Furse, 40, rushed him to Southampton General Hospital by car. 
There, the toddler was given an MRI scan and a lumber puncture. 
The day after his initial collapse, he was diagnosed with transverse myelitis, a rare condition of the central nervous system involving inflammation in the spinal cord. 
The doctor thought it had been caused by a virus but he hadn’t had a cold. The youngster is pictured in April 2015, about three weeks before he fell ill (Photo: PA Real Life) 
Karen said the virus attacked the spinal cord of the body, making it swell up. 
“The spinal cord controls movement and breathing in the body, hence why everything shut down,” she said she was told by doctors. 
The condition can be treatable, but unfortunately Archie’s case was extreme and his swelling had been too severe. 
It was a devastating blow for Archie’s parents. Read More Little girl can't stop crying after mum surprises her with adorable present 
The youngster had only just started walking seven months earlier, and it had not been long since he said his first words “mama” and “dada” and “Peppa Pig”. 
“It was heartbreaking to lose that, and to see him not being able to say anything, it’s been emotional,” Karen said. 
Over the next eight weeks in intensive care, Archie’s heart stopped 12 times, as it wasn’t receiving the correct signals from the spinal cord, leaving his mum and dad fearful they’d lose him over and over again. Archie, now three, is pictured in a specially designed wheelchair after he was discharged from hospital (Photo: PA Real Life) 
It was a terrible time for his parents. 
“Each time, the doctors said there was no guarantee they could bring him back and I’d think we were going to lose him,” Karen said. 
“I felt helpless, watching my child like that and knowing there was nothing we could do about it.” 
In August 2015, Archie underwent five hours of open-heart surgery to have a pacemaker fitted. 
This was the best option because his heart had stopped so many times by then. 
“I couldn’t believe this was happening to us,” Karen said. Read More Mum SNEEZED herself into labour after husband sprinkled pepper on his plate - so he had to deliver baby 
“It was a relief, because it would stabilise him, but it was also sad.” 
Now, he will breathe through a tracheostomy tube 24 hours a day for the rest of his life. 
In April 2016, after nearly a year in hospital, Archie was stable enough to move to The Children’s Trust rehabilitation centre in Surrey. 
There, he had physiotherapy to keep his limbs supple and speech therapy to help him talk. The little boy, pictured with his family, has had physiotherapy to keep his limbs supple (Photo: PA Real Life) 
That month, around a year after falling ill and while undergoing therapy, he said his first words again – “mummy” and “daddy”. 
It was an emotional moment – and from then on he went from strength-to-strength. 
Then, in November last year, the family were able to move into Karen’s parents Lin Adams, 64, and 69-year-old Ray’s house, after not being able to afford to keep their rented home. 
Archie, now three, was delighted to be back with his brothers, Lewis, nine, and Oliver, 23 months. 
Doctors don’t believe he will ever move again, but he continues to have therapy and is doing well. 
“He’s such a strong little boy and such a happy child,” Karen said. “Every day now he is saying something different and he has a huge smile. 
“He’s a fighter and that’s what keeps us going.” 
The family are fundraising to get a home adapted for Archie’s needs and specialised equipment to stimulate him by using his eye gaze. 
To donate, visit https://www.gofundme.com/ArchieAdams
